Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Quantum Size Effects in Semiconducting V2VI3 and IV-VI- based Thin Film and Bulk Structures and Control of their Thermoelectric Properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research with Karkhov Polytechnic Institute in Ukraine focuses on an experimental and theoretical investigation of the influence of size quantization of the energy spectra on the thermoelectric transport in V2VI3 and IV-VI semiconductors which are two categories of prospective materials for thermoelectric generators and cooling devices. The research includes: 1) a detailed systematic investigation of the thermoelectric properties of V2VI3 quantum wells (QWs) as a function of the QW width, charge carrier concentration and temperature; 2) an analogous investigation of the IV-VI QWs grown on (111)BaF2 substrates; 3) an investigation of the thermoelectric properties of bulk IV-VI-based composites with nanometer-scale inclusions as a function of the size of the inclusions and the distance between inclusions; and 4) the development of new theoretical models for electron and phonon transport in mesoscopic systems and nanosystems. The experimental and theoretical results thus obtained are of interest for understanding a wide range of effects where electron and phonon transfer phenomena play a major role. Effects connected with size quantization of the electron and phonon spectra will be studied in detail, the role of surface states and the classical size effect will be established, and recommendations will be made for applying these effects to control and optimize the thermoelectric properties of V2VI3- and IV-VI-based bulk and thin film structures and to create new high-efficiency thermoelectric materials.

In modern power engineering, special attention is given to the development of methods of direct energy conversion, as they relate to global energy sustainability. The work emphasizes the constantly increasing role of nanotechnologies in direct energy conversion, particularly in thermoelectric materials science. The active participation of students in the project promotes their learning the many basic experimental and theoretical methods used in nanomaterials science

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Materials World Network grant on quantum size effects in semiconducting thin films to control their thermoelectric properties involved a collaboration between the principal investigator Elena Rogacheva, in Kharkov, Urkaine, and the principal investigator Mildred Dresselhaus in Cambridge, MA, as well as their research groups at both locations. When materials are created so that their size along some direction is small enough to show quantum behavior, materials behave very differently from their behavior in bulk form. For example, a thin sheet of carbon atoms in a hexagonal lattice, called graphene, has electron motion very different from the behavior of multiple layers of the same type stacked together to make a solid graphite thin film with a thickness less than the resolution limit of an ordinary optical microscope. The public has been exposed to much press coverage about single-layer graphene, and the European Union has launched a 10-year Flagship Program funded at 1 billion Euros to study the structure, properties, and applications of graphene and graphene-related materials. Similar programs are ongoing in the United States, Asia, and elsewhere.

Under the Materials World Network grant, experimental studies were carried out by the Rogacheva group on thin films of bismuth and antimony from column V of the periodic table, which are known to be promising for thermoelectric studies. The thermoelectric measurements they made on these thin films contained mainly bismuth with a small concentration of antimony. The behavior of one particular set of measurements attracted the attention of the MIT investigators who were concurrently working on spectroscopic studies of graphene. The PI from the U.S. side of the collaboration asked graduate student Shuang Tang to investigate whether or not his model for the electronic band structure showed the possibility that the electronic energy could have an anomalous behavior similar to that which is commonly observed for single-layer graphene. This behavior corresponds to a linear dependence of the electron energy on momentum, like a relativist particle. His finding on how this was possible led to a publication which has by now attracted considerable attention and press coverage. Further developments have been followed up, largely motivated by public interest in this finding, including studies of the dependence of this effect on film thickness, antimony concentration, and crystallographic orientation of the film normal.
